description.narrative:
Den föreslagna insatsen innebär utökat stöd till Radio Waves, ett program för friare och mer oberoende media i Zambia implementerat av BBC Media Action och med särskilt fokus på lokalradions bidrag till ett bättre medialandskap i landet. Det ursprungliga Radio Waves beslutades och inleddes hösten 2014 och hade då en budget på 15 800 000 SEK för perioden 2014-2017 (ref: ZAM-DC58/2014). Det nu föreslagna, utökade programmet sträcker sig till och med april 2018 och har en budget på 32 900 000 SEK varav 3 300 000 redan har utbetalats inom ramen för det befintliga avtalet med BBC Media Action.
Radio Waves syftar till att stärka den professionella och organisatoriska kapaciteten hos lokala radiostationer i Zambia med avsikt att bidra till att Zambias civilsamhälle blir bärkraftigt och fungerar som en plattform för dialog och ansvarsutkrävande. Detta görs genom ett tätt partnersamarbete med de utvalda stationerna och genom att utveckla veckovisa debatt- och diskussionsprogram som speglar lokala frågor. Befolkningen i radiostationerna lyssnarområde deltar i val av aktuella ämnen och ger feedback till journalisterna. Programmen ställer lokala makthavare till svar för deras beslut och agerande och bidrar till en rapportering som bygger mer på sakfrågor och mindre på personjournalistik. Skälen till den föreslagna utökningen är flera:
Det utökade programmet ger uppenbara skalfördelar och möjligheter till ökade resultat i ett läge där de initiala erfarenheterna av verksamheten nu stödjer ambassadens tidigare bedömning av lokalradio som en särskilt viktig kraft i det zambiska medialandskapet.
Det föreslagna stödet adderar ytterligare fyra stationer till de ursprungliga sex. Radio Waves kommer därmed att nå ut till fler människor i fler provinser och möjligheterna till utbyte och synergier mellan stationerna ökar markant. Två av de nya stationerna är kommersiella aktörer vilket bedöms vara en tillgång i nätverket av radiostationer, både för genomslaget och för den långsiktiga finansiella hållbarheten i programmet, vilket har varit en nyckelfråga sedan starten av Radio Waves.
DfiD har för avsikt att genom Zambia Accountability Programme (ZAP) gå in med finansiellt stöd på cirka £1,2M/15,5MSEK till ett tvillingprojekt kallat "Zambia Speaks!" Det brittiska stödet föreslås så långt som detta är möjligt att harmoniseras med ett utökat Radio Waves. Tillsammans utgör projekten ett nätverk av 16 radiostationer runt om i Zambia vilket ger en goda möjligheter till kunskapsutbyte och sammarbete och framförallt ett samlat journalistiskt genomslag som är betydande.
2016 hålls parlaments- och presidentval i Zambia där medias urval och rapportering förväntas att spela en avgörande roll både före, under och efter själva valen. Ett utökat Radio Waves kommer att anpassas till valcykeln och bland annat rymma en komponent för mediebevakning av valrapporteringen genom Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA). Organisationen har lång erfarenhet av liknande insatser och kompletterar BBC grundkompetens för journalistisk träning. Ambassaden bedömer att det i det rådande och djupt polariserade medielandskapet är viktigt med insatser som synliggör eventuella oegentligheter under valperioden.
Det utökade programmet föreslås stärkas ytterligare genom en komponent som nyttjar ny teknik och sociala medier, bland annat genom att knyta samman traditionella och "nya" kommunikationskanaler. Komponenten innebär en innovativ ansats som väntas att stärka deltagandet, relevansen, ansvarsutkrävandet och räckvidden av Radio Waves.

The suggested intervention means increased support to Radio Waves, a program for a more free and independent media in Zambia, implemented by BBC Media Action and with particular focus on community radios´ contribution to a better media field in the country. The original Radio Waves was decided upon and initiated in the fall of 2014 and had a budget of 15 800 000 SEK for the time period 2014-2017 (ref: ZAM-DC58/2014). The now suggested, increased program reaches until April 2018 and has a budget of 38 600 000 SEK, out of which 3 300 000 already has been payed within the framework of the current agreement with BBC Media Action.
Radio Waves aims towards strengthening the professional and organizational capacity at community radio stations in Zambia, with the purpose of contributing to Zambia´s civil society becoming sustainable (bärkraftig) and functioning as a platform for dialog and accountability. This is done through a close partnership with selected radio stations and through developing weekly debate and discussion programs that reflect local issues. The population in the areas of the community radio stations participate in the selection of current subjects and give feedback to the journalists. The programs hold community leaders responsible for their decisions and actions and contribute to reporting based more on factual questions rather than subjectively chosen issues.
The reason for the suggested increase are multiple: The increased program gives apparent advantages in economies of scale and possibilities for increased results in a situation where the initial experiences of the activities now support the embassy´s previous judgement of community radio as a particularly important player in the Zambian media field.
The suggested support adds another four statins to the original six ones. Radio Waves will thereby reach out to a larger crowd in more provinces and the possibilities to exchange and synergies between the stations will increase significantly. Two of the new stations are commercial actors, who are viewed as being an assent in the network of radio stations, which has been a key question since the start of Radio Waves.
DfiD has the intention that through the Zambia Accountability Programme (ZAP) bring a financial support of approximately £1,2M/15,5MSEK to a twin project called “Zambia Speaks!”. The British support is suggested to as far as possible to be harmonized with an increased Radio Waves.
Together, the project make up a network of 16 radio stations around Zambia, which gives good possibilities for exchange of knowledge and cooperation and especially a collective journalistic breakthrough that is meaningful.
In 2016 the parliament and presidential elections will be held in Zambia, where media´s selection and reporting is expected to play an important role before, during and after the actual elections. An increased Radio Waves will be adjusted to the election period and will encompass an component of media coverage of the election´s reporting through the Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA).
The organization has long standing experience in similar interventions and complements BBC´s base competence for journalistic training. The embassy assesses that in the current and deeply polarized media field it is important with interventions that show eventual inappropriates during the election period. The increased program is suggested to be strengthen further by an component that uses new technology and social media, for example through connected traditional and new channels of communications. The component means an initiative aim that is expected to strengthen the participation, relevance, accountability and reach of Radio Waves.

description.narrative: Outcomes 3 and 4 are fairly new streams of work under the Radio Waves Project. As such the bulk of the work involved conducting training and various meetings to lay down the ground work for the bulk of interventions to be undertaken in 2019. Some examples of results achieved are highlighted below by outcome. Many of the results are as presented in the endline evaluation. Outcome 1 - Partner community radio stations have increased capacity to meet the needs of their audiences and to hold decision makers to account through their programmes - The quantitative endline survey revealed that 89% of listeners agreed or strongly agreed that the governance programmes provided them with a platform for dialogue on important local issues. This was 90% of males and 87% of females. (For regular reach, 91% (91% male and 90% females) agreed or strongly agreed). - The qualitative endline evaluation also suggests that the radio stations are successfully modelling meaningful and inclusive dialogue, by providing a balanced platform that takes all local concerns seriously and so prompts audiences to participate. - 83% of listeners in the quantitative endline study agreed that the governance programmes on Sida supported stations played a role in holding decision makers and local leaders to account for their decision and actions. Slightly more females said this (85%) than males (82%). Outcome 2 - Partner community radio stations have increased capacity to generate and manage resources sustainably. - Senior station staff interviewed during the endline evaluation indicated that trainings and mentoring received from BBC Media Action had benefitted the stations’ organisational capacity and sustainability. A specific area that many reported improvements was in financial management systems, with the new financial processes leading to more transparency. They added that the grant system introduced by BBC Media Action had helped stations to be accountable for money raised from other funders as well. Another area was human resource management with stations reporting improvements in structure, management and operations. Outcome 3: Communities, particularly young people, have increased opportunity to engage in dialogue on local development issues and hold decision-makers to account - BBC MA has supported the radio stations to increase their social media presence as a way of increasing opportunities for communities (especially young people) to engage in dialogue on local issues and hold decision-makers to account. All the radio stations recorded growth in their facebook pages ranging from 14%-238%. - The 'Ishiwi' (the Voice) page, which is the dedicated centrally managed social media page for the project, saw an increase in the number of likes from 91,802 in October 2018 to 106,053, translating in a 15.5% increase. The average engagement of people over 28 days was 8,699 with a total reach of 114,775. Of those who engaged, there were more females engaging on the page at 51% than males at 49%. The most engaged age group is between 18 years to 24 years followed by 25 years to 34 years, highlighting that the page is attracting its target audience of young people, particularly women. Content on the page includes animations, videos and pictures aimed at engaging young people on governance issues encouraging them to be active in their community. Outcome 4: The media sector is strengthened through having a stable, editorially sound and robust network MISA engaged decision makers on the Access to Information Bill (ATI), the proposed Cyber Bill, media regulation (self versus statutory) and strengthening of the Independent Broadcasting Authority (IBA) Act to be able to regulate both private and public media houses including Zambia National Broadcasting Corporation (ZNBC).
